LOCATION: 245 N Broad St suite 300, Philadelphia, PA 19107, USA
Text Description:
Improving the lives of the formerly incarcerated by providing low-interest loans, financial coaching, and community support.

The Fountain Fund is a nonprofit lender that provides low-interest loans and financial coaching to people formerly incarcerated (Client Partners), helping them build credit and achieve their self-determined goals. There is no other organization in the country providing very low-interest loans and financial coaching exclusively to previously incarcerated individuals.

The Fountain Fund offers required financial literacy training which  includes resources related to finances and credit building, group workshops and one-on-one financial coaching to give Client Partners the information, understanding and skills to build credit. In addition, the program connects Client Partners with various community resources to help them make the most of a fresh start and advocates for public policy that increases economic opportunities and reduces obstacles for people formerly incarcerated.
Secondary Contact Position: Executive Director, Penn Restorative Entrepreneurship Program

LOCATION: 315 S Broad St, Philadelphia, PA 19107, USA
Text Description:
Broad Street Love provides stabilizing services to those experiencing deep poverty. Rooted in dignity and care, we offer an open, safe space for hundreds of guests every weekday.

This is a non-traditional social service environment providing barrier-free, relevant, and responsive supportive services to a diverse community of Philadelphians. The organization's mission is to transform our city, our institutions, and ourselves by embracing the individual needs of our most vulnerable neighbors. BSL practices radical hospitality by embracing all individuals with enduring empathy and care. BSL reaches beyond the societal norms of service, confronts the injustices that oppress their most vulnerable members, and fundamentally shifts the expectations of how they engage with guests, staff, volunteers, and community partners. BSL sustains a fervor that one day this practice of hospitality will be pervasive and no longer be considered a radical act.

Text Description:
The Philadelphia Access Center began as a social services information and referral center. More than twenty years later, social services is still the largest part of our ministry. Our compassionate social service case coordinators meet with guests one-on-one to work through whatever issues they are facing. From navigating a crisis to simply answering questions, our case coordinators are here to be good neighbors to anyone in need.

Information, referrals, and advocacy are available for a multitude of resources, including (but not limited to) food, clothing, emergency shelter, housing, substance abuse, children's resources, senior programs, public assistance, and many others.

LOCATION: 1425 Arch St, Philadelphia, PA 19102, USA
704 W Girard Ave, Philadelphia, PA 19123, USA
Text Description:
FRP answers the call to social justice and ecological sustainability by supporting the marginalized and vulnerable in the Philadelphia region with housing, life-skill and job readiness resources through social services, partnerships, and programs for training and jobs.

Our Mission is to have a racially and economically just Philadelphia region where communities that once experienced economic neglect are thriving, and have safe, energy-efficient, and attainable housing opportunities, vibrant green space, and an abundance of resources to meet the needs of the vulnerable.

LOCATION: 1231 N Broad St, Philadelphia, PA 19122, USA
Text Description:
Our process starts with an in-depth evaluation that assesses work history, technical skills, and living situations and identifies other barriers to employment. After an in-person orientation and a one-on-one meeting with a job coach, clients are matched with an employer and placed in a job within 48-72 hours. Through partnerships with public transportation and Enterprise Rideshare, we provide clients with transportation to and from work. The First Step team also coordinates closely with other nonprofits to connect clients to resources and services such as housing, healthcare, food and clothing needs, and more that they need to develop a stable path out of poverty and homelessness.

Looking for more than just a paycheck? At First Step Staffing, we understand that the right job can open doors to lasting financial independence. We don’t just offer employment; we provide the opportunity to build a stable, fulfilling future.

When you join us, you gain more than a job—you gain access to tailored training, steady support, and the tools you need to grow professionally and personally. With the right guidance and confidence, a job becomes a pathway to success that can transform your life.
Main Contact Position: Vice President, General Manager of Philadelphia Region

LOCATION: 800 N Broad St, Philadelphia, PA 19130, USA
Text Description:
Founded on a vision of bringing transformation to North Central Philadelphia and beyond, People for People, Inc. (PFP) is a non-profit organization established by Herbert H. Lusk, II that is dedicated to bringing the kind of life-changing assistance to Philadelphians which helps them construct new futures for themselves and their families.

The guiding mission of PFP is to break the vicious, generational cycle of poverty in the lives of economically-challenged residents of Philadelphia by providing them with positive alternatives to drugs, crime, and welfare dependency. Recognizing the complex and inter-connected obstacles facing low-income urban residents, PFP provides support services to residents and links distressed neighborhoods with concerned leadership and available resources. PFP facilitates the development of personal responsibility, accountability and self-reliance.

Text Description: Since 1917, the Urban League of Philadelphia has worked to make a difference in our community. As a proud affiliate of the National Urban League, one of the nation's oldest community-driven movements, our focus has always been on helping disenfranchised urban communities thrive. Our mission is to support Black Americans and other historically marginalized groups by promoting social equality, economic independence, and civil rights. We do this through programming for youth, education, job training, housing, workforce development,  re-entry, entrepreneurship, economic development, and health equity. With the support of a strong board, skilled staff, and passionate volunteers, we’re committed to building a future where everyone has the opportunity to succeed.
Secondary Contact Position: Director, Office of Housing and Diversion Services

LOCATION: 1952 E Allegheny Ave suite 500, Philadelphia, PA 19134, USA
Text Description:
Since 1974, we have been working in the Kensington neighborhood of Philadelphia to help people re-enter the workforce, find stable housing, and help build community. Over the last two decades we have also built a continuum of housing services in an effort to end homelessness.

The foundation of our work lies in our ability to nurture partnerships with other mindful organizations. By aligning missions, resources, and creativity, we’re able to muster the latent energy in our community.

Company Name: I'm FREE -Females Reentering Empowering Each Other
LOCATION: 4700 Wissahickon Ave, Philadelphia, PA 19144, USA
Text Description:
I’m FREE – Females Reentering Empowering Each Other, a woman-centered organization, advances the life chances of women transitioning from corrections to community by advocating for gender-responsive, trauma-informed care; providing consultation to agencies and offering innovative services for the women and their families.

Our vision is to create an innovative, interactive model using best practices and infusing therapeutic and holistic approaches to guide formerly incarcerated women to self-sustaining lifestyles. 

It is our intent for every woman to reconnect with society and her family with the help of our services, revitalize her sense of purpose, and renew her mind; thus, freeing herself from an institutionalized way of living.

LOCATION: 302 W School House Ln, Philadelphia, PA 19144, USA
Text Description: Sisters Returning Home is an organization that provides services to the growing population of women who have recently been released from Philadelphia county jails or Pennsylvania State correctional facilities. The organization's client, reentering women, face a unique set of challenges, including homelessness, substance abuse, physical and mental health problems, and a lack of social and familial support. Sisters Returning Home's programming is designed with these challenges in mind in order to provide comprehensive support to meet their clients' needs.

Text Description:
Provides mental health and substance abuse treatment services to individuals with disabilities, including those experiencing homelessness or re-entering the community.

We embrace a vision of recovery, resilience, and self-determination through a model of care that is directed by the person in recovery. In this model, professional treatment, along with family, individual, and other resources, allows people to manage their own conditions and build their own recovery resources.

We also help people with intellectual disabilities live self-determined lives in their communities by providing quality support and services.

Text Description:
The School District of Philadelphia and SEPTA provide free trans-passes to students who live 1.5 miles or more from Building 21 Philadelphia. When the trans-passes are delivered to the school, they will be accompanied by a list of students who are eligible to receive one. You will receive a free trans-passes ONLY if your name appears on the list. Free trans-passes will be distributed once a week during Advisory.

Trans-passes are for use from 6:00 AM to 7:00 PM
No evening or weekend use is permitted
Adults may not use SEPTA Student trans passes
Learners will be responsible for the safety and security of the free learner trans-pass
Lost trans-passes: Each learner is expected to maintain the safety and security of the free trans-pass that was issued. Principals will notify the parents about lost trans-passes. Parents will be required to purchase a trans-pass to replace lost passes.

LOCATION: 1340 Frankford Ave, Philadelphia, PA 19125, USA
Text Description:
Lutheran Settlement House (LSH) is a multi-service non-profit on the border of Fishtown and Kensington. LSH has been serving the community since 1902 through various programs, adapting and responding to the needs of the community at the time. Currently, we offer domestic violence counseling and prevention programs, a family shelter in North Philly, a food pantry, family caregiver counseling, and a senior community center.  Our mission is to build a support system and community for individuals in crisis so that folks can have the stability that everyone deserves and to be able to focus on the things that really matter to them.

Established in 1902, Lutheran Settlement House (LSH) is a non-profit, community-based organization committed to serving children, adults, and families living in Philadelphia. Over the past century, the programs and services offered by LSH have changed in response to the evolving needs of the community. However, the core mission of Lutheran Settlement House — “to empower individuals, families, and communities to achieve and maintain self-sufficiency through an integrated program of social, educational, and advocacy services” — has remained constant.
Notes:
● Food Access
– Meals for Seniors
Weekly grocery distribution, Meals daily at 11:30am
– Food Pantry 
Monday through Friday 9am-3pm
– Community Meals 
Third Thursday of every month
– Holiday Meals 
Holiday food distributions occur as they become available.  Thanksgiving basket distribution usually occurs the Tuesday before Thanksgiving, and advance registration is required. The Thanksgiving Distribution will be announced in October along with registration information.

Text Description: The Center for Carceral Communities, an initiative of the School of Social Policy & Practice at the University of Pennsylvania works collaboratively with neighborhoods in West Philadelphia to help people with a history of incarceration re-engage with the community. We provide free, evidence-based psychosocial services that address the mental health, educational, housing, advocacy and primary care challenges confronting those returning to the community. The Center seeks to reverse the community-to-prison pipeline by helping participants harness their strengths and become leaders in the community.

Text Description: This program quickly places people experiencing homelessness into temporary housing. Once housed, individuals or families are set on a path to secure permanent housing.

Text Description: This program assists individuals with chronic mental illness live in a group home setting.

Text Description: Serves women who come from shelters by providing a safe and supportive home where they may live for up to twelve months while developing self-sufficiency.

LOCATION: 345 Montgomery Ave, Bala Cynwyd, PA 19004, USA
1515 Fairmount Ave, Philadelphia, PA 19130, USA
Text Description:
Project HOME's Outreach Coordination Center (OCC), in partnership with the City of Philadelphia and other service providers, coordinates outreach to people living on the streets of Philadelphia.

Outreach response workers build trusting relationships that enable individuals who are homeless to accept placement in appropriate settings where they may obtain needed opportunities to stabilize their lives. The outreach teams attempt to establish a rapport that gradually leads to acceptance and openness to seeking help.

Outreach teams conduct street outreach almost around the clock seven days per week, with additional teams out during summer and winter weather emergencies.

LOCATION: 2826 W Diamond St, Philadelphia, PA 19121, USA
Text Description: Project HOME provides supportive housing, employment assistance, and other services to help individuals break the cycle of homelessness and poverty.

LOCATION: 2013 Ridge Ave, Philadelphia, PA 19121, USA
Text Description: The Philadelphia Housing Authority offers affordable housing options and support services for eligible individuals and families.
